line: important comparison is inter-temporal - how is aggregate EU retail food
label: paragraph

line: concentration changing over time? Unfortunately, here, we are confined to just a comparison of our own
label: paragraph

line: estimates for 1993 and 1996. Nevertheless, even over this relatively short three year period, there appears
label: paragraph

line: to have been a significant increase in EU concentration. As shown in the table, there was an increase of
label: paragraph

line: 4.2% points in the share of the top 20 between 1993 and 1996. Moreover, the table and figure 1, which
label: paragraph

line: show the cumulative concentration curves for the two years, reveal that the increased share of matrix firms
label: paragraph

line: is almost entirely attributable to the top 20. Indeed, the next 30 firms actually suffered a joint loss of 0.4%
label: paragraph

line: points between the two years. This is due, presumably, in part to the rapid growth of the very largest firms,
label: paragraph

line: but also in part to the exit of some important medium-large firms, as described in the previous section.

line: 7.4. Concentration within individual member states
label: heading

line: Tables 7.4 to 7.6 turn the focus on to concentration within the individual member states. Table 7.4
label: paragraph

line: confirms that the above increase in concentration at the EU level is mirrored by typically increasing
label: paragraph

line: concentration in the individual member state- by about 3% points on average between 1993 and 1996.
label: paragraph

line: It also confirms important differences between member states. Broadly speaking, the ranking of member
label: paragraph

line: states is as described in the previous chapter. The highest 5 Firm concentration ratios are to be found in
label: paragraph

line: Finland and Sweden, and the lowest in the southern countries - Greece, Spain, Italy. The UK, France and
label: paragraph

line: Germany lie within the middle of the range. Perhaps most interestingly, there appear to have been
label: paragraph

line: significant increases in concentration in Portugal, Spain, Austria, Greece and the UK. Moreover, since
label: paragraph

line: these estimates refer to 1996, they will not reflect the effects of continued merger activity post-1996 in
label: paragraph

line: Spain, Portugal and the Netherlands in particular.
